sessions.title: Authenticating with REST-ful Web API's
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 200

These days, a lot of web applications are using OAuth 2.0 as the preferred means of authenticating and granting access to 3rd parties to interact with their REST (Representational State Transfer) API's (Application Programming Interface). Interacting with the API is usually a fairly simple task, but overcoming that first hurdle of authenticating via OAuth can be difficult if you're unfamiliar with it! Particularly if you don't have access to your own web server to easily complete the multi-legged flow of the OAuth 2.0 authentication process.

In this session we'll discuss what OAuth 2.0 is and why and how it is used. We'll also go through a real world example of using OAuth2.0 to obtain a token and we'll do it all using common command-line tools. This session is targeted at students and developers with 1-3 years of experience and some basic understanding of web application development.

sessions.title: Expanding Your Hadoop Ecosystem
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 300

Although Hadoop is a critical part of any big data strategy, it isn't sufficient by itself to adequately empower a data science group. Organizations can better enable their data science teams by building up a robust software ecosystem around their Hadoop platform. Data scientists need flexibility and choice to create effective workflows. This talk will describe how organizations can make their data scientists as effective as possible by thinking more broadly about their big data software portfolios. Self service data provisioning systems, real time ingest and alerting platforms, central data cataloging strategies, and other complimentary storage platforms will be discussed. An emphasis will be placed on building effective data science workflows through the use of software tools centered around an enterprise Hadoop storage and computing environment.

sessions.title: Facade of Truth about Agile
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 200

Target Audience: Development Managers, CIO/CTO, other executives, Scrum Masters, anyone interested in Agile and reasons it might not be working in their business.

There are six "apparent truths" sitting just behind the "agile facade":
1) agile isn't just a process, practice or even methodology, it requires organizational change to be done well
2) there is no one definition of what it means to be agile - therefore anyone can claim it without actually being it
3) Agile, without some technical architecture conversation is a faster way to hell!
4) Agile is a quality initiative, same as lean manufacturing and design-build
5) Scrum is one of many agile approaches and it is severely lacking in technical and business discipline
6) Agile requires a collaborative and facilitative leadership skill set

Without a good understanding of these factors most firms these days are utilizing agile as a process or tool; and are missing the huge returns they could have if they were focused on building productive human interactions (first line of the Agile Manifesto).

sessions.title: Is Thought the Future of Wearable Input?
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 100+

The Brain-computer interface is a mainstay of science fiction, and devices are available today to use our brainwaves as a computer input. But is it practical? How far away is it? Will "Big Brother" read our thoughts and hack our brains?

The answers to these questions and more, including a live demo of a brain-computer interface used to fly a Quadrocopter.

In this class, we will dive into the future of thought as input for wearable devices with real-world examples and code. Demonstrations will be shown using the Emotiv EPOC headset, a revolutionary high resolution, neuro-signal acquisition and processing wireless neuroheadset that uses a set of sensors to tune into electric signals produced by the brain to detect thoughts, feelings and expressions.
 
You will see the EEG neuroheadset and computer interface with examples. We will dive into the roots of the technology, showing code and examples along with big pictures of the technology. You will walk away with an understanding of how this still evolving and largely unknown technology really works, how it can be used, as well as longer-term implications.

Real leadership create followers who themselves become leaders. Real leadership is exhibited through eight traits which can be learned and practiced and implemented throughout your career and this session will teach what they are and what you need to do to become a leader.

sessions.title: ABCs of Modern Web Marketing for Developers
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 100

For active developers, you've probably encountered more marketing-oriented projects in your work. More and more, developers must be conscious of how marketing and business considerations should effect their projects. If you're a freelancer or owner, or have your own projects/products to market, you may also need to know about marketing for yourself. This session will cover 1) many of the modern techniques and newest developments of web marketing including websites, search, social media, mobile, web apps, usability, integration, messaging/branding, rhetorical function, and stakeholder concerns, 2) applications of these to help developers shape their projects, and 3) applications of these for marketing your own projects or business.

sessions.title: Agile Panel
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 200

This session will be a panel discussion about the different approaches to Agile in the market place. There are many different situations where one particular practice approach may or may not be as useful as another. We want to explore the practical usefulness of various forms of Agile as well as try to clear the air on misunderstandings that arise out of perceptions of some practices. We will be talking about Scrum, XP, Lean, and other forms as well as exploring frameworks like SAFe, DAD, and more. In this Panel discussion the participants in the panel will be asked a question and we will explore the answer from the perspective of different approaches to Agile. The audience will have a chance to ask questions as well and interact with the form as they have their discussion.

sessions.title: Big Data Is a Big Deal - Running Hadoop in the Cloud
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 100

You will leave this session being able to understand and explain what Big Data really means. This session was given at Silicon Valley Code Camp to 200 attendees. It received one of the highest evaluation scores at the world’s biggest code camp.

This session is designed to give you a solid understanding of underpinnings and principles of Hadoop, perhaps the most sought after high-paying skill for a developer today. The in-depth session will begin by illustrating on how you build your own single node cluster of Hadoop on the Linux virtual machine (CentOS) for free so you can start learning immediately.

The session will begin with a raw Linux VM and all the needed components will be downloaded and installed. You can be up and running quickly in the cloud within 30 minutes. This session will contain code and will show no more than a few slides.

We will learn about writing the low-level map/reduce code in Java, which is really the assembly language of Hadoop code. From there we will introduce more efficient approaches to analyzing big data with Hadoop, running high level queries and analyzing crime information from San Francisco as the example. We will create tables, import data, and group crime types all with a simple SQL like interface that is Hive.

Finally, we will include a brief talk on PIG as well to round out the high level programming models and additional follow up materials so you can be up to speed on one of the most promising and financially rewarding skills today.

speakers.name: Sean Scott
speakers.role: Oracle Core Database Administrator and Architect

sessions.title: SQL Patterns in Practice - You're (Probably) Doing it Wrong
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 100

Despite being "Structured" Query Language, there's not much structure required to write SQL. However, poorly formatted SQL makes debugging and editing more time consuming and inefficient than it needs to be. Bad examples of SQL abound and have found their way into the mainstream as practitioners adopt the methods they find on popular web sites and blogs into their own repertoire.

This presentation is appropriate for anyone who uses SQL, no matter how seasoned. It introduces pragmatic design patterns for writing SQL that make it easier (and more enjoyable) to understand and edit. Based on over 25 years of applied experience with SQL as a primary programming language, these techniques are are relevant to any implementation of SQL, including Oracle, MySQL, SQL Server and PostgreSQL.

sessions.title: (Un)conventional Android Development
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 200

Android applications have a tendency to become complex, piles of spaghetti code that are difficult to maintain and update. But, creating an Android application doesn't preclude you from following good engineering and coding practices.

If you have ever found yourself maintaining (or even writing) Android applications with the following problems:

  • Activities with 1000's of lines of code coupled with fragments with 1000's of lines of code
  • Complex signaling between background tasks, services, and activities
  • Application Not Responding messages
  • Database locking

In this session, we will explore some standard software development patterns as they relate to Android application development, including some of the SOLID principles and the GRASP principles. Additionally, I will show you some of the conventions and tools that I use when developing Android applications that can mitigate the aforementioned problems while increasing your velocity.

I am also an artist. I co-founded Enso Artspace, an artist collective with an exhibition space located in Garden City, Idaho.

sessions.title: Using Fabric.js for Interactive HTML5 Canvas Applications
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 100

Whether you have built something using HTML5 native canvas functionality or are just canvas curious, this session will show you the possibilities that Fabric.js brings to simple or complex canvas applications.

What Is Fabric.js? It’s is a powerful and simple javascript HTML5 canvas library that cuts down on lines of code and provides a simplified canvas API. It allows you to easily add images and text as objects on the canvas. Objects can be moved, rotated, resized and more, and is written in an object-oriented way so that it can be extended through subclasses.

This session will be rich in demos and code examples. For the past two years Kelly has been building a large canvas-based educational application using Fabric.js that is ultimately used by students and teachers via wireless smart boards. Kelly will be sharing examples and learning from her first-hand experience on that project.

sessions.title: What Is a Virtual Environment and What Is a Storage Area Network?
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 100

A basic or intermediate introduction to networks, storage area networks and VMWare virtualization. The session will include an introduction into hardware abstraction both of server and storage.

Sometime during the session the presenter will give away an HP Proliant G5 1U server with VMWare 5.0 installed and ready to go into your test lab.

There are a number of dials that your network, server and SAN administrators can 'turn' to improve performance for your applications. Come and learn more about the black box of virtual servers and walk away with new understanding and with some ideas about how you could utilize virtualization, snapshots, dev and test environments. We will also delve into storage area networks and discuss performance tuning of storage.

sessions.title: A More Humane Web
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 100

Common practices are not best practices! When it comes to the web, many sites have an unfortunate habit of annoying, pestering, excluding, or even being downright hostile to their own visitors. Is your site one of them? "Features" such as auto-playing slideshows, modals on page load, and so on impede visitors from finding the information they're looking for - and may even drive them away. This back-to-basics presentation will serve to remind site developers and stakeholders that content is king, accessibility is prime minister, and everything else is a distraction from the mission of inviting and informing your site's visitors.

We will discuss an architecture for testability and the tests that we need to write to know we are shipping high quality code.

speakers.bio: What? I build websites at http://valice.com

speakers.role: Web designer, amateur food maker, husband, and father.
speakers.speaker_bio: I am a web designer at the local hosting company, Valice. I design and build websites for small and medium size businesses. I am passionate about web technology and user experience design.

sessions.title: CMS Free Websites (With Bonus Content Management)
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 200

As the number of features in a content management system grows with each new release so does the complexity and size of the code base. Many project scopes use a very small set of CMS features. Additionally, every CMS is extremely opinionated. If you need to diverge from how the CMS accomplishes a task then it might as well be like moving a mountain and clients end up baffled why a "simple" change to existing functionality is so expensive.

Static site generators are very popular these days. They make creating small custom websites a breeze. They output simple HTML, CSS and Javascript so hosting is inexpensive and plentiful and if you are used to working with CMS templates and custom plugins then they are easy to learn as well.

In this session I will walk through a setup for creating simple websites that are easy to maintain using Jekyll, Github and Prose.io.

This session was inspired by this blog post http://developmentseed.org/blog/...

"Entertaining your Cat with Ruby" is a session created to showcase not only the ease and simplicity of the Ruby programming language, but also demonstrate the Artoo (http://www.artoo.io) micro-framework for controlling robots.

Using Artoo's DSL for the Sphero, I'll walk through the building of simple scripts as well as more complex choreographed routines for the ball-ish robot, as well as walk through the initial setup and install of required software.

This is an introductory level session due to it's goal of humor and fun with only a fundamental understanding of code. Attendees will obtain an introduction to how easy and affordable programming robotics with Artoo is, as well as see a few ruby tricks in the process.

Final slides and code samples will be completed by March 1st.

sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 200

AngularJS is a client-side Javascript framework that will allow you to become a better front-end developer. It encourages good design practices and is a natural evolution if you find yourself developing complicated jQuery-based web apps. You'll learn what AngularJS is and how to use it with code examples that will be yours to tinker with after the presentation. We'll also discuss why you should consider using AngularJS in your next web app.

speakers.name: L. Paul Verhage
speakers.speaker_bio: I'm president of the Boise Robotics Group (the BoRG)

sessions.title: Get Your Robotics On
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 100

Last May, the BoRG taught eight families to make their first robot. We started with families who had never picked up a soldering iron or digital multimeter. The class was offered through community education, which is part of the Boise school district. At the end of four weeks, most of our families has soldered a robot brain, made a robot body, and programmed their new robot to follow a line. The class was made more affordable by the donations we received. The December 2013 issue of Servo magazine has an article about the class.

This presentation will explain how the class operated, our results, and some of the lessons we learned. We plan to offer this class again and would like to pass the word and encourage more mentors to participate.

sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 100

In this Bruno will go through various Windows Azure capabilities including: Virtual Machines, Cloud Services, Websites, Mobile Services, Storage and the Building Block Services. A demo of the Azure management portal through a simple ASP.NET web application with show the power of Windows Azure service deployment and operational model. There are many things to understand about posting applications in the cloud, scaling these applications, and accessing new storage models that are hosted in the cloud.

If you plan to interview for a job anytime soon, regardless of whether you are interested in learning the Amazon cloud or the Microsoft cloud, I will cover the key pillars of knowledge you need to have succeed in an interview.

sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 100

Have you ever wondered what it might take to win a scholarship to Apple's Worldwide Developer's Conference (WWDC)? Do you want to know more about WWDC?
During this session, I will share how I started coding at the age of 11 and how you can get started too. I will also share with you my winning app for the 2013 WWDC scholarship competition, and some of the code. I’ll also give you a sense of what goes on at WWDC, and why you might want to attend. speakers.role: Release Engineer at Bodybuilding.com
speakers.speaker_bio:
I've worked in Web application development for more than ten years including the past five at Bodybuilding.com. I'm currently a release engineer with the goal of moving our organization forward in our processes and tools to where we can practice continuous delivery.

I'm also a grad student in computer science at Boise State. My research is focused on static analysis and symbolic execution.

Outside of work and school, my interests include DIY projects around the house, photography, and solving a variety of unusual Rubik's cubes.

sessions.title: API-ify Your Web Apps
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 200

These days a Web app shouldn't remain just a Web app. It should be built as a service that can be consumed by other apps regardless of language or platform. Mobile apps are a popular choice. In order to support remote access by mobile apps (or any access using other languages), your Web app needs an API.

In this session, we will retrofit a simple PHP Web app and build a REST API for it. Then we'll create client libraries in Java, Python, and Ruby to interact with our new API. The target audience is anyone who wants to take their Web apps to the next level. Although PHP is used for this session, the concepts are applicable to any modern programming language.

sessions.title: Bring Your Web Application to Life Visually, Using D3 (Data-Driven Documents)
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 100

This introductory session will cover a discussion (including live example demonstration) of the D3 JavaScript library (d3.js) to explore its powerful graphing capabilities using SVG (Scaled Vector Graphics) to showcase your data. D3 is easily added to the front-end of your web application. We will show you how D3 allows the developer, using a data-driven approach, to bind arbitrary data to Document Object Model (DOM) elements, and then apply transformations to the document with powerful visualization components. D3 is known to be fast, robust, supporting large datasets and dynamic behaviors for interaction and animation. With an emphasis on web standards, D3 gives the developer full capabilities of modern browsers without tying your project to a proprietary framework, allowing flexibility to build a data visualization framework you want. The session will also demonstrate how to rapidly prototype data visualization using an experimental development environment.

sessions.title: Deep Dive into Key Pillars - Infrastructure as a Service, Platform as a Service - What Does This Mean?
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 200

There are two main approaches to writing applications for the cloud. The traditional approach (infrastructure as a service) is to create and set up VM’s. This approach allows you to install just about anything on a machine running in the data center. But is somewhat of a manual process and doesn’t scale that easily. A better approach is to leverage the technology known as, platform as a service, which allows developers to focus on the application and its data, not on the underlying infrastructure, which is abstracted away with this approach. Anyone that claims to know cloud computing needs to understand the pros and cons of each architectural approach. This session will provide concrete examples and demonstrations of how it all works and ties together. Anyone looking for a career in the cloud will be very well served by understanding the underpinnings presented in this session.

speakers.speaker_bio: David Shepherd is a software tools researcher, turned professional tools developer, turned software tools researcher and open source contributor. You'll also find him evangelizing the merits of better code search tools at conferences like devLink. He lives and works in the RTP area where he leads ABB's Software Engineering Research Group.

sessions.title: Regex Searches: Ain't Nobody Got Time for That!
sessions.abstract:
Session Level: 100

Developers are busy people, running from sprint to sprint, with little time for self-reflection. They don't notice how often they mutter "..how'd he implement that.." or "..where's that method that does X?" They don't notice that the search tool they use to answer these questions is from the 1960s. They don't even seem to notice that 90% of these type of searches fail! Fortunately, a developer turned researcher did notice, and has dedicated the better part of the last decade to eliminating this quiet productivity-killer.

In this talk, I'll use both video examples and a massive repository of real developer activity data to prove that the typically-used regex searches waste a significant part of your day. Yet this talk won't dwell on the past; it focuses squarely on a better search future. I'll provide a tour of Visual Studio's many built in searches, demonstrate two search tools available as extensions, and provide guidelines for better searching. By attending this talk you will become a more effective searcher, a skill that is surprisingly fundamental to software development, and I estimate you can eliminate 10-30% waste from an average sprint.
